chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Reform should keep the Constitution’s state-administered structure while narrowing the gap between the national vote and the final outcome, so no region feels ignored and no small set of states dominates campaigns. A workable compromise is to curb winner-take-all by defaulting states toward proportional elector allocation (with flexibility for local implementation) and to consider a national popular-vote trigger only once a broad coalition of states adopts shared rules. Whatever path is chosen should include clear baseline standards for ballot access, certification timelines, transparent audits, and automatic recount thresholds to make results easier to verify and harder to dispute.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should preserve a meaningful state role while making each vote count more equally and reducing winner-take-all, swing-state distortions. A practical path is to encourage proportional or district-based allocation of electors and, if broadly adopted with clear guardrails, an interstate compact that aligns the outcome with the national popular vote. Any changes should be phased in and paired with uniform baseline rules for ballot access, transparent post-election audits, and clear recount/certification standards so results are simple to administer, verifiable, and widely trusted.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Preserve a meaningful role for states while ensuring the president reflects the will of the people by making every vote count more evenly and reducing winner-take-all distortions. A practical, state-driven compromise is to encourage proportional or district-based allocation of electors, paired with clear national baseline standards for ballot access, secure counting, transparent audits, and automatic recount triggers so results are reliable and widely trusted. If broad bipartisan support develops, states could also adopt a carefully designed interstate compact that aligns the outcome with the national popular vote only when enough states join to avoid instability and gamesmanship.
